metadata.name: Potential LSASS Process Dump Via Procdump
metadata.comment: Detects suspicious uses of the SysInternals Procdump utility by using a special command line parameter in combination with the lsass.exe process. This way we are also able to catch cases in which the attacker has renamed the procdump executable.

batch.sql: SELECT * FROM process_activity WHERE time BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AND (lower(activity_id) = lower('1') AND (contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' -ma ')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' /ma ')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' –ma ')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' —ma ')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' ―ma '))) AND contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' ls')))

output.summary: Detects suspicious uses of the SysInternals Procdump utility by using a special command line parameter in combination with the lsass.exe process. This way we are also able to catch cases in which the attacker has renamed the procdump executable.

metadata.objective: False positives: 1. Unlikely, because no one should dump an lsass process memory 2. Another tool that uses command line flags similar to ProcDump Reference: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/procdump
